title: FlexMesh tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: These are some tools I designed to hold the subs in place to make it easier to clip them in (i.e., for kids who might have trouble).

comments.text: Can you take a video of this? I can't seem to figure out how it works.
comments.author: tdannecy

comments.text: I got a chance to print your tool designs overnight and play around with them a bit this morning. It's a very useful way to bring leverage for tight fitting connectors and for kids who are used to an easier fit like Legos. I like the flexibility you designed into the Main tool of the pair. It's wide enough for the biggest pieces, yet rigid enough to protect from delamination that can sometime happen when the fit is tight. Subs slip right into the other tool and to just the right depth to allow clearance to accept the Main. I'm sure it was also helpful in your discovery of the 2.1 Subs being too high.
comments.author: neobobkrause

comments.text: Thanks for the comments! I thought a little about a unified tool, and could make a long one (just sticking them end on end) but that wasn't very elegant. Making a more compact version would be possible, but might require overhangs on the print which I didn't want to do. Or a really thick version to avoid overhangs, hmm.

title: Minelab Sovereign GT custom lithium polymer (lipo) battery pack holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a custom battery holder for use with a Minelab Sovereign GT metal detector. It fits the AA battery pack lid cover and allows the use of a lithium polymer (lipo) battery which charges faster, makes the machine lighter, lasts longer than the standard nimh battery pack, can be recharged instead of just thrown away, etc. Many benefits to this type of battery. This is designed to fit a Turnigy 11.1v 1450mah lipo perfectly. You MUST use a proper lipo compatible charger to charge this sort of battery. You can just remove the contacts from the original AA battery pack and use either the futaba or JST type connectors plugged into a female connector and all soldered together. Some warnings:
Make sure to observe polarity or you will fry your machine. Do not short circuit a lipo or it will go nuclear. Do not get a lipo wet.

You may need to turn the print 90 degrees depending on the size of your print bed. Heated bed recommended.   
Print it out, remove original wires and contact points from bottom piece of original tray. Connect a female futaba or JST compatible connector. Solder together. Job done.

title: Mini FPV Tricopter - Split for small print volumes

description.text:
This is a remix of EMaglio's Tricopter that can be printed on an up mini or any printer with a build area of 120 x 120 x 120  
The original battery cover can simply be rotated 45 degrees to fit within that space, however I have included a split cover for smaller print areas.

I would recommend printing these parts in PLA with no supports, 4 outer layers and 20% infill as per the original design. If you have a single layer raft at the base you can trim this off the tongue side and use the other side to help join them together. I use acetone glue to join the segments together but epoxy would work too.

It's very convenient to have a power switch for your printer easily accessible. But accidentally cutting power in the middle of a print will ruin anyone's day. So protect it with a nuclear-missile-launch-button style case!

This case is made in 3 parts and employs the simplest hinging method possible. The actual button it is designed for is Adafruit's illuminated latching on/off switch. (https://www.adafruit.com/products/1443) The case cover has 2 legs that stick into the case bottom to create the hinge. Those 2 legs have significant overhang which my printer was not able to print. To resolve this I simply flipped the STL over in my slicer and printed it legs first up to the point where my first print failed. Then sanded and glued the pieces together.
Its a quick print that uses a 8mm rod to hold your filament spools and mounts easily to a Solidoodle printer.
Peg is 5.9mm in diameter. Perfect for 6mm pre drilled holes.
Made with Tinkercad.

I was bummed to find out that the Nexus 6 did not have the alignment magnets that the Nexus 5 did for docking onto the wireless charger which made it annoyingly difficult to try and carefully line up to charge.  This docking cradle will properly align the charger with the Nexus 6 as well as present the phone at a 45 degree angle.  
The wireless charger is flush with the surface of the cradle once the sticky tape is removed from the bottom of the charger.  
I've included the source SketchUp files for others to remix which includes the finished model as well as the sample cradle object that was printed to ensure alignment.

comments.author: Roaders

comments.text: Hey, yeah, I printed this on my own and it only costs about $3 in PLA filament ($6 if you buy the "premium" priced stuff) and the electrical cost is negligible.  It uses ~42m of 1.75mm plastic according to Simplify3D.  For 70 pounds you'd be on your way to just purchase your own small-scale 3D printer!  I looked up a few different websites and the general pricing structure is pretty outrageous!  I guess they're really marking up the per-hour rental cost since that's what's at a premium in this case.
comments.author: Roaders

comments.text:
A lot of the sites seem to price on the total volume of the model and not the volume of material used which is why this is expensive (one site quoted about £300!).
I have some ideas to make this a much smaller model but I really don't think that my non-existent skills in 3D modelling are up to what I have in mind!

Cabin

This adapter allows you to connect most any phone to most any eyepiece. Like a microscope, telescope, etc! I am always working on new stuff to print. If you interested in being the first to know when I release something new, then check out http://arsenalproducts.wordpress.com/be-the-first-to-know. 3D printing goodness!

Parts List: Qty 6: 4-40 x 1/2 Socket Head Cap Screw (McMaster 92196A110) Qty 1: 2.5" x 1/4" OD Spring (McMaster 9657K171) Qty 1: 1/4" x 1-3/8" Clevis Pin (McMaster 97245A242) Qty 1: 1/16" Cotter Pin (McMaster 98335A044) Qty 1: .56" Dia x .063" wire x 120 deg Torsion Spring (McMaster 9271K641) If you do not want to buy the quantities above from McMaster (~$50 total) I have plenty of leftovers and can send them to you for $10 + actual shipping. If you are interested, you can reach me at [email protected] To assemble: 1) Screw the left cap onto the left slide and the right cap onto the right slide. It really helps to start the screws a few turns in each of the holes first then take them back out and assemble the two parts. 2) The recess down the center of the right slide has to fit over the square piece of material underneath the left slide. After the right slide is over the square piece of material the two pieces can slide together. 3) Feed the spring through the hole in the bottom of the right slide (BE CAREFUL! Wear some glasses so the spring doesn't shoot out and hit you in the eye!! You think it won't happen, but it will) 4) Load the celvis pin through the bushing then screw the bushing to the bottom of the right slide. 5) Next put the 2 clips together to install the torsion spring. 6) This is by far the most difficult part of the assy process and once again, BE CAREFUL! Wear some glasses so the spring doesn't shoot out and hit you in the eye!! You think it won't happen, but it will... Squeeze the long arms of the torsion spring together and insert inside the back of the clips (it way help to wear some time of gloves because the ends of the springs can be sharp). While you are still holding the ends of the spring, take the slide assembly and place the clevis pin through the larger hole on the top side of the clips, thru the spring and thru the small hole on the bottom side of the clips. 7) Once the clevis pin is thru the bottom hole of the clip then put the cotter pin thru the small hole at the end of the clevis pin. 8) You will need to trim the ends of the spring with a diagonal cutter. Trim them short enough that you will not cut yourself on the trimmed ends when using the device. One thing to note is that these holes were sized to work well on my printer . You may need to make the holes larger if the resolution on your printer is different. The clips should move very smoothly otherwise they will not grip the eyepiece very well. These were printed on a printer with support but were designed to work on a printer without support. Let me know if there are any issues. You can see other projects of mine at arsenalproducts.com.

This is a red-green-blue LED blinking light Christmas tree.
It is designed around a PSOC 4 prototype board (CY8CKIT-049 4200).
You can get one for about $4.
The rest of the project (schematics and C code) is on GITHUB:
https://github.com/peter-gregory/BlinkingTree.git

The STL files are in inches.
If they appear very small, you will need to scale them by 25.4 to convert to millimeters.
The tree parts are designed to be printed without supports.
I printed them on a Cubex Trio (single color used for print).
The parts should press fit together.
To wire up the LED array, I attached wires to the LED leads and joined them together inside the tree's hollow space using ribbon cable.
The 16 lines for the LED matrix goes into the project housing to the board.

title: General purpose extruder #4
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
One-piece body with integrated filament tensioner based on Gregs's Wade original.
Redrawn in HeeksCad to make it easier to integrate with my other projects. This is easier to print and assemble than my earlier general purpose extruder and should be easier to use as well. Designed for use with a J-head hot end on an aluminium plate . Standard mounting hole spacing should work with any existing mount for Wade-type extruders. Use this is preferece to the earlier http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:50659

Print it out 2-3 shells and about 40% fill.
Use with my 45/11 gear set or any other should work also. You need:
3 x 608 bearings
1 x 8mm rod 20mm long (or M8 rod works as well).
2 x M4 mounting bolts and nuts.
1 x hobbed bolt, washers and nuts. Clear out all the idler tensioner bolts and the filament hole with a 3.5mm drill.
Clear out the mounting holes with a 4mm drill.
Fit the idler 608 bearing without the 20mm axle rod.
Gently prise the idler ope enough to slip the idler axle through the idler 608 bearing (the idler printed hinge is very flexible so shouldn't break).
Fit the other two 608 bearings and hobbed bolt.
Complete the extruder with your stepper motors and chosen gear set.

Keep your Blizzard BattleNet authenticator... inside a hearthstone!  
Provides device protection, increased geekiness, and a quick trip back the inn of your choice. ;)  
Also, the authenticator's  keyring fits out the top so you can hang this if you want to (or it can just sit on a shelf).

PRINTING:
I printed this in white PLA, 25mm layer height, 1 shell, 15% infill. Then cut the two halves off the raft and clean up ant stringies.
.
The dovetail is made over-tight on purpose. File all mating surfaces with a half-round file until they fit snugly, but not too tight.
.
Also paint the hearthstone symbol if you like.
.
.
EDITING INSTRUCTIONS:
To modify this thing, download the scad file from the original authenticator this is a remix of, as well as the original hearthstone stl -- they must be saved into the same folder!
.
Next, open the scad file and scroll down to the "hidden" section.
hearthstone_box=true .... generates the box
front=true/false ..................creates either the front or the back of the box

description.text:
Simple to print medium sized hex. Arms are from home depot and are dirt cheap http://www.homedepot.com/p/Best-Value-Centura-24-in-Replacement-Towel-Bar-in-Polished-Chrome-E8500A-24/100388799?N=5yc1vZbz9qZ12kx
Everything needed can be printed or purchased at Home Depot (maybe others). It flies very well, nice and stable and very predictable. The motor mounts need a bit of a redesign. They tend to snap right at the end of the arm.... but still better than ruining a motor. Total AUW with battery (No FPV gear) = 1750 grams. UPDATE I have uploaded a revised motor mount (v6) that is much tougher than the v5 mount. Let me see those makes!

I used ABS, .3 LH, 30% infill with honeycomb. The Pictures tell the story of how it's built, pretty cut and dry. Through-bolt the frame and arms with 6-32 screws, washers and nylon lock nuts. Motor mounts are through-bolted with M3 screws, washers and nylon lock nuts. GoPro, Battery and Boscam 600mW transmitter are all held in place with o-rings from harbor freight. FPV tray bolts to the landing gear with M3 screws. Battery saddle clips are held in place with M3 screws and a small o-ring. Cover need some M3 screws and nuts with rubber bands looped under the arms to hold it in place. There is also a filler tray x-brace to help keep the landing gear stiff if the FPV tray is not used. Battery for FPV is a Zippy Compact 800mAh
Main Battery is a Turnigy Nano-Tech 4500mAh 35-70C.
The saddle and battery blocks were designed around this battery. Others may work but may need new designs or tweaks. I have included the .DWG files for the motor mounts, battery parts and FPV tray if someone wants to adapter them to different batteries, motors, etc.

description.text:
The names says it all...  
Hole in the back for round 3 mm x 10 mm Neo magnet.  
Super glue required to attach the parts.

Another Redneck Linear, but this one gets the job done! This very universal Linear can be used with several sizes of motors from 270, 360, 370, 380 up to the 540. Uses 5/16-18 all thread rod and spinning hex nuts for motion. You are only limited with the linear travel by how long of threaded rod you can get. Has a range of gear ratios that can be uses to get the right speed and power you need. Will mount up several different ways and has mounts for miniature micro switches. Can mount up and push or pull through a bulkhead. You can use all or part of the linear depending on what you need it to do. Small enough to fit beside a 2 by 4 with motor laid on side. With motor speed controller linear could be used to move about anything with remote control.
The liner has two different A cases depending on the motor you want to use. The 540 case will handle most motors with 25mm mounting holes 1.409" case and 10mm bearing housing (550 will work with larger pinion gears, but you better fasten it down good!). The 380 A case will handle motors with 16 and17mm bolt centers, max motor OD of 1.092". The 540 case will go down to 93-14 gears and the 380 will go down to 93-10 gear ratio. Just added a .PDF gear ratio chart that shows what gears you can use and their ratio.
The spool (A gear - B gear) sandwiches a drilled Team Associated slipper clutch style spur gear with 1.25" octagon in between the halves with 5/16-18 hex nuts inside for contact with all threaded rod. Uses two 18x12x4mm sealed RC truck bearing on the spool. The Team associated gear I found easily on Amazon, they have a 93, 87, 84 and 75 tooth 48P gears. To figure the speed of the linear use the following example. The motor I am using is a Mabuchi RS540SH-7520 (purchased 4 of them new off ebay for $12.60), it is a 7.2V, 12A, 312 g-cm of torque at 19,000 RPM. The gearing is a 93 spur gear and a 14 tooth pinion, divide the pinion teeth by the spur teeth you get .1505 multiplier. Multiply your motor RPM times this number (or the spool is turning .1505 (15.05 percent) of the motor speed). 19,000 RPM times .1505, that is 2860 RPM that the spool is turning at the threaded rod. Take the RPM's at the rod times the thread pitch of the all threaded rod which is .05556 (that is how far it moves with one revolution of the spool). The rod moves 158.8" inches per minute, divided by 60 seconds is 2.648" of movement per second. With the 84-33 gear ratio and this motor it would have 6.91" of travel per second. That is wipin right along! If you use smaller motors with lower RPM things will slow up a lot, you will need torque to get taller ratios and speed. With the 540 motor and 93-14 gears with the liner case chucked in my vise it dead lifted a 5lb hammer and didn't even strain. But the RS540 is a powerful high Amp motor.
Need to talk about how to wire it up and the micro switches. You have to understand that I know just enough about electricity to get me in trouble! So please research your motor and ratings of switches to be safe. The RS540 motor is rated at 12Amps DC Volts. If you use micro switches to run the motor itself, be sure they are rated for 12Amps at DC volts not VAC. Big difference, most sub-miniature micro switches will only handle a fraction of the DC Amps that the switch will work with in AC Amps. I am using an Arduino board and a 2 channel relay to control the linear. The micro switches cut off the low 5 volts, .020 amps of the Arduino board through the relay, not the 12A of the motor. When get more time I will do some different wiring schematics for automotive relays and toggle switches, but there is already a lot of info online on this subject.
The micro switches have holders that will go on at several angles, and the case will rotate for placement of motor on top or sides. The switch triggers have 5/16 nut inside and one for a jam nut. Can be adjusted up and down the rod for the right shut off point of motor with switch.
Linear uses #4x3/8, #4x1/2 and a couple #4x3/4" sheet metal screws. Uses 1/4-20 bolts in the mounting bracket and yoke. You will need to drill with a "F" bit and tap the yoke to 5/18-18 thread.
Sill working on this so stay tuned for updates as I use it and get the switches working.
I tried printing some gears but they didn't turn out round enough or strong enough to work with that powerful of a motor at 19,000RPM. Just added some Team Associated Spur Gears to download. You will have to try them and see if they will work for the smaller motors. I would use a metal or plastic manufactured 48P pinion gear for the motor. Have fun and be safe!
Update June 2015: Hey everyone I found a really nice motor from Jameco #2144673 Mabuchi RS555PH-2330. The motor has 380 g-cm of torque and does it at a slower 5050 rpm. Much easier to manage and only 4amps at 12-30 volts. The motors are $3.95 each. I am using one on a new project lifting a 15lb metal blade on a RC Dozer and it has a lot more power than the RS540.

Walking mechanism that allows a toy to walk down a slope. It is duplo compatible to ease adjustments. Snap 2 identical walker assemblies (for front and rear legs) on a duplo 2x4 unit, add more duplo units for weight and aesthetics and let it walk down gently sloped board.

To make a walking toy you will need 2 identical walker assemblies. Each assembly consists of a base (walker-base-?.stl), an axle (piece of 3/32" wire, I used a piece of welding rod), 2 legs (walker-leg-?.stl) and a spacer to keep legs on the axle slightly apart (walker-clip-?.stl) For convenience all printable parts for 2 assembiles are collected in walker-all.stl. Snap the assemblies on a 2x4 duplo unit, add more duplo units for weight and aesthetics and let it walk down gently sloped board. I used a duplo top model, which I can no longer properly attribute since I cannot find a link to it any more. It is included under the name ext-duplo.scad

description.text:

The other modification is the use of a M3 nut with the nylon ring. I find that this helps to prevent the screw from backing off.

author: Tob1112

description.text:
A machinist jack is a simple but extremely useful tool used in machine shops for leveling and supporting parts in a vice. It is particularly useful for long parts and parts on angles.
Consider this an affordable albeit light duty alternative to a steel set: (Steel version linked on amazon here: http://amzn.to/28MtWex)

I printed everything at 50% hexagonal infill. I recommend using a light support that you can easily remove after printing such as a 6mm pattern spacing, 6mm interface pattern spacing, and 1 interference layer  
The blocks are designed for a 1.25" long fully threaded 5/16" bolt. (I used a nylock nut and threaded rod in the photo because I didn't have a fully threaded bolt available.)

LIL MAN
Simple coaster with Dallas Cowboys logo etched in.

Designed coaster using 123D design then took Dallas Cowboys logo and etched it out in center.  
In order to make multicolor, I watched the print in Pronterface and when it started the layer with the base of the inner etching, I paused it, changed colors and resumed. Once it completed the base of the etching and the first row above it (noted by seeing the outline of the etching), I paused again and changed back to the original color and resumed.  
Updated now with additional layer so you can add in white as well.

description.text: This hub will fit on the Generation 5 Makerbot and allow you to use 1kg rolls.  I sized this hub to fit the rolls from justpla.com but it may fit other rolls too.  Just leave the filament door locked up and you can use the stock tube as well.  Add a small amount of grease to the hub if you feel it is adding friction.
No supports are needed.  If you want a raft that is fine or you can print right on the glass using Aqua-Net hair spray and no raft.  I used standard medium settings.

author: mkomi

remixed_from.author: LucidOne
remixed_from.title: TriK Tripod Adapter for the Kinect

title: Kinect Tv mount
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
My brother called up one day with a dilemma. He needed to mount his Xbox Kinect on his plasma TV, but didn't want to spend $40 on a cheap looking commercial mount. Knowing that I have an awesome 3d printing bot (which he usually says i'm wasting my time with), he gave me a few measurements of the TV to design a mount.
I already saw the trik tripod adapter and liked the design a lot, so I took the original STL file and started taking point geometry from it to create a new solid model. I then printed it and went to his house. Every thing fit well! Now it's mounted and has been in service for about a month.
***I'll get some pictures up after next week when I go and visit.

Print, cleanup, take four plastic tapping screws or wood screws, as mentioned in the original thing's instructions. Carefully line up the Kinect on the tv and use a m5 screw in the back to keep it on the tv securely. You may need to shim it a little in the front.
Accepts TV's 1.5" thick.

comments.text: Well I have a junky cell phone picture, of the mount. It printed quite well, even the fancy bevels.

author: antohneeo

description.text:
Use this device to identify energy inefficient light fixtures by their low frequency flickering! All you do is spin the top and look for a blinking bluish line to see if you could be using a better light fixture!  
Why This works: Fluorescent light bulbs flicker at twice the AC frequency because the magnetic ballast driving them is directly affected by the AC current peaks. So 60 Hz AC = 120 Hz flicker. Newer more efficient solid state fluorescent tube lights flicker at a much faster rate. This top has high contrasting colors spaced in such a way that when spun at low speed it will create a frame rate interference, just like when you look at your TV through a digital camera.  
The photos taken with the bluish lines are what you see with slow flickering light, the other two photos used sunlight which doesn't flicker and just makes a red white blur.   
NOTE: Some LED's have low flicker rates and will give you a false positive. Don't throw away your energy efficient LED's!

You have to print the 'top body' with a high infill to make sure the top layer doesn't have any gaps which will make it hard to paint and degrade the flicker effect. The top handle and tip both require some light support generation. I would recommend printing them with no less than 30% infill so you they don't get broken in use. I also super glued the top and bottom in place but they are sized for a functional press fit. Note from the last two photos that you could just as well use a pen to get the same effect, you don't have to make it into a top. For the best results use high contrasting colors such as black and white. (Red & white worked just fine for me.) I used white out to paint the top surface. EDIT: I added a quick video explanation here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wvpb0BYwnmw&feature=youtu.be

title: Printrbot Simple Metal fan holder for extruder

description.text:
The simplest mount for a 40mm (Or I guess any size) cooling fan on the extruder of a Printrbot Simple Metal. You know, that great direct drive extruder that gets so toasty it partially melts the filament before it reaches the hot end? Yeah, that. Took me 14 minutes to print. Include a recessed and properly sized hole hole for the nut, which fits flush.  
Yes. You do want this part. It fits great. It lets the fan pivot. It can split the atom! DOWNLOAD!

Increase size by 25.5x, and print on its side for best results. The current orientation will work, but won't be as strong. 3 walls, 3 top/bottom layers, 100% infill, .3 mm layers. Requires the original screw that went up into the extruder block (M3x8mm), 1 or 2 washers, an M3 nut, and an M3x16mm bolt. If you still have the spare vitamins from your printrbot assembly, these are included in that little baggy.

comments.text: This finally stopped the issue of my filament getting clogged and the extruder gear grinding it down to dust. Greatest change I've made to my Printrbot so far.

The inspiration for this project was the lack of organization I have in my closet and garage.  So I designed a way to customize a hook system that can be scaled small enough for sets of car and house keys to large enough for brooms and rakes, etc.  And since you can never have too many hooks, additional units can be printed and snapped together before screwing them to the wall.
Not only is this the first design I've ever done in OpenSCAD, it is the first design I've ever done for a 3D printer.  And since I don't have a 3D printer of my own, I'd appreciate feedback from anyone who prints this design for themselves.  I'm already working on version 2!  :)

After setting up your build plate, select the type of component that will be printed.  A  "Start" does not have a connecting pin at the beginning of the part, just as an "End" doesn't have one at the end.  A "Middle" part has a connecting pin at both ends, and a "Solo" part doesn't have one at either end, as it is intended to function independantly.  From there, select the height of the hook system (in millimeters - the length and thickness will be determined automatically), the number of hooks you'd like print in one piece, and finish by selecting the type of "hook" for each number of hooks selected.  If you'd like to leave a gap between hooks for bulky items, select "Blank" for the hook type.

title: Yam Stool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The goal of this project is for the pictured sculpture of the Yam Stool to be fully reproduced, (consisting of 24 printed pieces making 8 full yams and clamp mounts- mounted to a stool as pictured). As part of planning an exhibition, I am seeking collaboration to fully realize and facilitate the sharing and complete reproduction of this sculpture. I hope for a response and exhibition collaborator! please contact me if able and interested at [email protected]
I am based in Baltimore MD While I have an ideal goal for this project, I encourage any full yam to be reproduced and attached to modify any structure. The clamp fits best around a 3/4" tube and is tightened with #6 screws

This is Ideally printed on any plastic extrusion printer using any available color of plastic: PLA, ABS, or other plastic composite. The yams pictured are printed in various colors of PLA and are mounted to a solid steel stool built with 3/4" rod. There are 7 .stl files provided that are needed to make the ideal structure. Each yam is made from 3 pieces: a yam bottom, a yam top, and the clip backing. The files includes 1 yam bottom, and 3 matching tops each with a different angled clip. The variety of angled clips give a choice of orientation important if mounting multiples on a straight framework. There is a distorted yam bottom and a distorted yam top. All yam tops use the standard clip backings that print in strips of 5.
Once printed, the two halves of a yam are connected with 3mm rods (welding rods or any 3mm stock) to form a yam. The clip backings are secured to the yam using #6 screws.

title: Stand for Freedom Scientific Ruby magnifier

description.text:
This really is a niche application. It'll be interesting to see if anyone at all downloads it.
My eyesight is deteriorating and I recently started to use my late mother's Ruby magnifier to read the clues of the Sydney Morning Herald cryptic crossword which I attempt over breakfast (but not Friday's one which is usually totally baffling).
I got sick of holding the magnifier so designed and made this stand.
The stand is specialised in two ways, specifically for the Ruby magnifier, and at a height which at minimum magnification shows the full width of the clue and still large enough for me to read it with ease.
Designed in MOI, and made on a Robox using Robox ABS.

Easy to make just make sure that you orient the parts appropriately before printing.
The holes are sized for 3mm screws.
I used 3mm x 8mm long (OAL) button head cap screws.

title: Gearbox Keychain with Loose Gears
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is the Umake Gearbox Keychain, the only difference being I enlarged the hole in the gears .2mm to make assembly easier and the gears spin freely without sanding. When trying the original gears, I broke the tabs for one gear, and the other was so tight it wouldn't spin at all.   
I thought too many people were complaining about the tabs breaking when inserting the gears for it to be a coincidence or "bad quality filament". In a later comment, it was noted the designers were not using PLA, but PLA/PHA blend for best results.  
In studying the model I saw there was only a .2mm tolerance between the tabs and the gears, so I opened it up to .4mm (the same as my extruder nozzle). The result? Gears snapped right in place without any damage and spin fairly easy without any sanding.  
Printed with PLA "bad quality filament." The sample shown was done with .1mm layer, 2 shells and 40% infill on a CTC Dual.  
I hope this helps others enjoy this great design by Umake!  
Note: The keychain has not been modified, I only included it so all the parts would be in one download.
Just print and press gears into place. I did wipe a single drop of oil on the tabs "just in case", but I dont think it is needed since the tolerance are looser than the original design.

description.text:
Remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:566592 with the following improvements:
  • Battery can now be slid down to reveal camera, to allow pictures to be taken (kind of hard to submit portal suggestions using the rear-facing camera...)
  • Added "button hole" to allow the status button on the battery to be pressed.
  • Optional snap-in button to allow actuating the battery status button with your finger (vs. some narrow object that fits through the hole).
  • Smaller "strap slots" (see note in instructions).

One change from the previous revision (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:566592) is that I changed the "strap slots" -- (that I actually don't use) that are intended to allow using a camera strap of some sort that can attach at each end -- to be simple rectangles. The original had triangular "tops" specifically to avoid the need for support when printing. Now that they have horizontal top surfaces, support will be generated for them. That bad part about that is that (at least for the Slic3r version I'm using) support is generated inside nearly the entire length of the internal slot made for the strap (up to the top slot) -- I didn't notice that in the code preview. Once it was printing, I figured I'd let it finish and see if the support material could be removed. It took some doing, but I found that using a hacksaw blade (which fits in the empty slot), I could successfully remove the support material.

The outlet allows the exhaust to be piped out a widow.
30 cfm fan didn't cut it. I used a 62db 100cfm 80mm fan from ebay (http://www.ebay.com/itm/130654982712). Model is: FFB0812UHE . Requires a 12V 2A supply unfortunately. With this setup, no ABS plastic smell is apparent. Good thing too, because my health was being negatively affected by the ABS fumes.
I used plastic insulation sheeting to shore up the top of the outlet to the top of the window opening.
Considering to install another fan at window side to help airflow. Also will come in handy to disconnect the hose and reverse this fan's direction to force feed fresh air inside - since opening the window for ventilation will no longer be convenient.

title: Christmas Star - on top of the tree or as ornament

description.text:
In the files section you will find the complete star to print - but to accommodate larger sizes of the star I decided to divide the star in to easy-to-print parts (I recommend this approach though it requires assembly afterwards - prints easier and without support).
The star is at a 1:1 scale for what I like to use on top of the tree - but feel free to scale it to fit your needs (just remember to scale each part the same). Merry Christmas! (See instructions)

No infill and 2 shells to provide strength - but do as you please, this star prints easy. Star assembly:
2 x Center pieces
5 x Regular points
Print the 6th point to suit your need:
1 x Ornament point (with a hole in it for a string)
1 x Rod point (with a hole for a rod so it can be attached to a Christmas tree)
1 x Regular point (If you want a regular star) Depending on the accuracy of your printer you may need to sand the bottom edges for them to snap in to the center piece. Fix with a dab of glue.

description.text:
I wanted to transform used soda bottles into Moineau Pumps.... unfortunately, I couldn't quite pull it off so am shelving it for now until I can come up with a better solution.  
Basically, the pump does not move enough volume upwards to outweigh the rate that water can seep through gaps between rotor and stator.  
Applications of both silicone and plasti-dipÂ® were attempted to increase the seal between rotor and stator, but both were stripped away in a relatively small number of rotations.

1) Drink a soda
2) Want to do something with the bottle
3) Fail

comments.text: Perhaps a slit along the contact area, with a strip of neoprene, or rubber squeegee (like windscreen wiper blade stuff) pushed into it?

author: rialeiro

description.text:
UPDATE: There is something coming for this but I just got a new apartment so all spare time is going into moving.
So I decided to put emmetts differential planetary gear on a nema17... I wonder what we could do with that now? (answer is coming)
Ripped the code from gregs x-ends, adjusted ratios and size to get a fairly decent gear that should be printable and fit between the mounting holes of a nema17 and mashed them together. This is the result. yet to print it but its all scad code so fairly simple to modify.
Too hot to fire up printer atm, air con is struggling as it is. So yet to test this.
NOTE: no linkages yet so still has the hex hole in the center so if you can find a hex nut with a work in the side that fits use that. otherwise wait or come up wiht your own.
print the parts put spacer in if needed (most steppers have a raised bit in the center that needs to be cleared) bolt it on. Wont drive as is yet as still designing the linkages.

comments.text: While this would be no use for the axes on your 3D printer (due to minimum extrusion speed), it would be amazingly useful for the main spindle on an eggbot. The torque multiplication may even add enough strength to use it as a lathe. I only have an old 3 deg/step motor on hand to build one for my hackerspace and have been putting it off since the resolution would be too poor. If this prints decently it'll be worth making now.
comments.author: Blufires

comments.text: Do you think this homeprinted gears would be precise enough to make the z-axis steps on a reprap type printer smaller?
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text: depends on how low you can get with the tolerance. Honestly though my rep rap is currently at 3200 steps per mm without any gearing, using this to gear it down further would be 185600. it would take forever to move the z axis... that and its so fine you would never use it, cause you cant drop the flow rate of the extruder beyond a certain point
comments.author: Sungod3k

comments.text:
This looks great -- I was looking for a way to achieve gear reduction in a small package for a stepper (trying to build an improved bowden extruder). One thing I noticed -- I don't think this is going to work without a fixed planet carrier, as the planets will simply spin around instead of rotating the output shaft. That said, it should be quite simple to make one.
That said i'm printing one right now and I'll try a few things with it once it's done.

author: rickdegreef

title: Remote focus attachment for Newtonian telescope

description.text:
This is a remote focus attachment for an 8 inch Newtonian telescope. I suppose this is mostly useful together with a PC-controlled camera, where you can focus without disturbing nor being near the telescope. Automated focus would also be possible with some suitable software, although I have not tried this. The attachment is split into one part that attaches to the focuser base, and one that holds the servo. In addition there is a cup that connects the servo axle to the focuser knob. This makes it possible to revert to manual mode when needed, or to adjust the range of focussing, simply by removing the part that carries the servo. The design is parametric within reason, so you should readily be able to adapt to other size telescopes, other focusers and other servos. The RC servo can be used as is, which will provide a repeatable focus (within the mechanical limitations of the focuser - always approaching from one side will help). This mode will limit travel to about half a revolution of the screw, which is enough for most cases. A simple interface is to use a common RC servo tester (available for $5 or so) as the controller, powering everything from the 5V of a USB port. More sophisticated setups would control the servo by a computer, for instance a tiny Arduino. The alternative way is to strip the internals of the servo, and use only the motor and the gears. In this mode, there is no limitation to travel, but also no feedback on the absolute position. A simple 3 position DPDT switch (spring loaded in both directions ideally) can be used to control the motor. Yet another alternative is to use a continuous rotation servo, like this one, available from Pololu: http://www.pololu.com/product/2149 (I have not tried this nor verified its suitability) You will also need:
1 powerful RC servo, e.g. HK15328A, with mounting hardware as supplied
5 M3x20 screws (3 is really enough)
3 M2.5 countersunk screws with nuts for the knob to servo adapter, or simply use a foam pad with glue
All 3 items should build readily from the STL files, without support and with little or no need for cleaning. I used PLA.

Here are plans for a simple caliper, handy to have around the shop for measuring thickness and diameters. Anytime I can build something that helps me build something else I am always pleased. 
The plans should be as accurate as your cutter or printer is, I actually used this project as a collaboration for my laser. 
For updates on my other projects and things check out: 4volt.com/blog/

If you don't have a laser you can print the PDF and glue the paper down to any flat material and cut it by hand. 
In the case of a laser, I engraved the markings and painted them, then sanded off the extra paint. 
After the paint is dried and sanded, assembly is simple. The lower caliper arm is bolted to the other sliding parts with 4- m3 bolts. The lower caliper arm has a few millimeters of adjustment space so you can change how tight the slide is.

comments.text: My friend brought a digital caliper into the lab a few months ago and I just freaking love the thing. I'm elated to know the sizes of stuff around me. Thank you for making this :). And making it in metric :). (i spent 20 minutes trying to convert it to metric anyway)

description.text:
I have need to mount a motor in such a way that I can adjust its position perpendicular to its shaft axis.
This thing has slots in it that will take a M3 sized screw.  it also has a big M4 hole in the middle if you want to mount that way.
There's not much to it, and I forgot to save my other longer winded Description, so here it is.

1) Figure out how many nema 17 motors you need to mount
2) Print one of these things for each motor
3) Use screws, or whatever means you like to attach the mount to whatever you're attaching it to.
4) Use the appropriate screws to attach your nema 17 motor to the mount
5) Rejoice!
This is a cool looking robot that i have put together. enjoy :)

  • No need for modifications afterwards!
  • Strong and sturdy design to keep it save from high drops.
    • The black/grey stuff (on the screw-thread) you see in my picture's is some graphite for dry lubrication. (update 16-12-2014, Made the cavity were the 3d mouse sits in slightly bigger. Also made the cavity were the knob of the mouse sits in a little bigger from 54 to 56.) (update 1-3-2016, Made a redesign!!)

I printed it on my orca 044.
Took about 8 hours.
I used 2 perimeters and an infill of 40%.

comments.text: This is great! There needs to be more stuff for 3D connexion mice!
comments.author: FlyingMashedPotatoes

author: iwant3d

title: Dalek Penny Bottle Opener and Whistle

description.text: This is a mashup of multiple thingiverse parts. Mainly props to InnovationByLayer's Doctor Who Dalek http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1600. I've added a Coin-op Bottle opener modeled after Hoeken's variation http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1813 . Finally, I've tacked on the thin profile whistle from TeamTeamUSA http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5416 (Take that Makerblock! http://makerblock.com/2011/01/your-argument-is-invalid/ )

dalekcoin.stl prints out just the bottle opener.  dalekfull.stl is bottle opener and whistle.  The latter is of greater difficulty so if your machine isn't well tuned I'd recommend the coin opener.
I use .3mm layers and have upgraded to v3.4 Stepper Motor Drivers (much quieter!)  Still working on the whistle part though.  I've updated my latest iteration which should be much improved.

comments.text: This was a good test after calibrating for me. Â My way of testing is to print something, hand it to my 2 year old daughter Molly, and if she says :Yay daddy made dalek!" I know it must be a closr resemblance!
comments.author: JonTheHorrible

comments.text: Really cool to see my dalek being used like this :) thanks!

comments.text: Thank you!  Obviously you did all the heavy lifting on this.
